docs.text: Documentation, Help Guide and Portfolio for OpenFOAM. Hosted on GitPages, built using MKDocs.

docs.title: Welcome to the Case Studies
docs.text: This section contains the case files and outputs of CFD workloads I have run using OpenFOAM. Files for anything from Tutorials will also be here.

docs.title: Welcome to the CFD Theory Section
docs.text: This section aims to explain the theory behind Fluid Dynamics and how is applies to Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD)

docs.title: Symbols
docs.text: List of symbols that will be referenced in Theory, Tutorials and Case Studies.

docs.title: General Variables
docs.text: \(q, s\) \(~~~~~~~~~~~\) Scalars \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}, \mathbf{c}\) \(~~~~~~\) Vectors \(\mathbf{S}, \mathbf{T}, \mathbf{Y}\) \(~~~~\) Tensors \(x, y, z\) \(~~~~~~~\) Cartesian Coordinate System \(\mathbf{I}\) \(~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~\) Identity Tensor \(\mathbf{\Psi}\) \(~~~~~~~~~~~~~\) General Parameter: scalar, vector or tensor

docs.title: Geometry and Mesh
docs.text: \(\mathbf{C}\) \(~~~~~~\) Cell Centre \(\mathbf{C_f}\) \(~~~~~\) Face Centre \(\mathbf{n}\) \(~~~~~~~\) Normal Vector of Unit Length \(\mathbf{p}\) \(~~~~~~~\) Point Location \(S\) \(~~~~~~~\) Surface \(V\) \(~~~~~~~\) Volume

docs.title: Numerical Methods
docs.text: \([\mathbf{A}]\) \(~~~~~~\) Matrix of a Matrix Equation \([\mathbf{A}][\mathbf{\Psi}]=[\mathbf{B}]\) \(\mathbf{A}\) \(~~~~~~~~\) Matrix of a Matrix Equation \(\mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{\Psi}=\mathbf{B}\) \(a_{i,j}\) \(~~~~~~\) Matrix Coefficients for row \(i\) and column \(j\) \([\mathbf{b}]\) \(~~~~~~~\) Source Vector of a Matrix Equation \(\mathbf{b}\) \(~~~~~~~~~\) Source Vector of a Matrix Equation, above \(c\) \(~~~~~~~~~~\) Scalar Coefficients MORE TO ADD

docs.title: Subscripts
docs.text: \(b\) \(~~~~~~\) Boundary Value/Gradient \(D\) \(~~~~~\) Downwind Interpolation \(ex\) \(~~~~\) Exact Solution \(f\) \(~~~~~~\) Values at Faces \(L\) \(~~~~~~\) Linear Interpolation, Lower Bound Value \(N\) \(~~~~~\) Neighbour Cell \(P\) \(~~~~~~\) Owner/Current Cell \(U\) \(~~~~~~\) Downwind Interpolation

docs.title: Superscripts
docs.text: \(c\) \(~~~~~~\) Current Stored Value \(n\) \(~~~~~~\) New Value \(o\) \(~~~~~~\) Old Time Level \(oo\) \(~~~~\) Old-Old Time Level

docs.title: Dimensionless Numbers
docs.text: \(Co\) \(~~~~\) Courant Number = \((\Delta t/{V})\Sigma_f \cdot \phi^+\) \(Pe\) \(~~~~\) Peclet Number = \(\phi_f~/ (|\mathbf{S_f}|~\alpha_f~C_{\Delta})\)

docs.title: Physical Quantities (SI units)
docs.text: \(\mathbf{b}\) \(~~~~\) Body Force per Unit Mass \((N \cdot kg^{-1})\) MORE TO ADD

docs.title: Dimensionless Numbers
docs.text: \(Eu\) \(~~~~\) Euler Number = \(p_0~/U^2\) \(Fr\) \(~~~~\) Froude Number = \(U~/ \sqrt{gL}\) \(Kn\) \(~~~\) Knudsen Number = \(\lambda~/ L\) \(Ma\) \(~~~\) Mach Number = \(|\mathbf{u}|~/c\) \(Pe\) \(~~~~\) Peclet Number = \(U L~/ \alpha\) \(Pr\) \(~~~~\) Prandtl Number = \( u~/\alpha\) \(Re\) \(~~~~\) Reynolds Number = \(U L~/ u\) \(Re_ au\) \(~~~\) Turbulent Reynolds Number = \(k^2~/ \epsilon u\) \(Sc\) \(~~~~\) Schidt Number = \( u~/D\) \(Sr\) \(~~~~\) Strouhal Number = \(L~/(\mathcal{T} U)\)

docs.title: Relational Symbols
docs.text: \(a=b\) \(~~~~\) \(a\) and \(b\) are equal \(a \approx b\) \(~~~~\) \(a\) and \(b\) are approximately equal \(a \simeq b\) \(~~~~\) \(a\) and \(b\) are almost exactly equal \(a \equiv b\) \(~~~~\) \(a\) and \(b\) are equivalent \(a:=b\) \(~~~\) \(a\) is assigned the value of \(b\) \(a \propto b\) \(~~~~\) \(a\) is proportional to \(b\) \(a \sim b\) \(~~~~\) \(a\) is of the order of magnitude of \(b\)

docs.title: Credits
docs.text: Weller, H. Greenshields C. (2022) Notes on Computational Fluid Dynamics: General Principles. Available at: CFD Direct, Notes on CFD (Accessed: 09 January 2025)

docs.title: Welcome to the OpenFOAM Tutorials Section
docs.text: This section is essentially my docs and help guide for OpenFOAM, aimed at making getting into CFD and Linux as smoothly and pleasantly as possible (T&C’s Apply)

docs.title: Admonitions
docs.text:
List of the admonitions that will be called out in Tutorials and Case Studies.

Warnings, pay careful attention to these.

Dangers, AVOID THIS UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE. There will hopefully be very few instances.

Tips, following these may or may not streamlines your workflow.

Notes, these serve as reminders/notes.

Examples, where I will try really really hard to explain tricky content using an analogy.

Contain codeblock/outputs of expected Success. Well done you’re competant, yaay....

Contain codeblock/outputs of Failures. Most of these will come from GitHub Issues. Well done you’re competant

Values that will be used in the solve.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: A step-by-step walkthrough on installing OpenFOAM

docs.title: OpenFOAM Installation
docs.text: OpenFOAM is available to install on MS-Windows, Linux and MacOS.

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
There are three different ways to run OpenFOAM on MS-Windows (10 or newer). In their order of preference:

  1. WSL/WSL2: Windows Subsystem Linux

    – Many OpenFOAM users prefer using WSL.

    – Provides maximum flexibilty.

    – The OpenFOAM Linux packages are kept more up-to-date than cross-compiled/Docker variants.

  2. Native Windows: Cross-compiled Windows binaries (mingw)

    – Quick way to use OpenFOAM on Windows.

    – Does not currently include an OpenFOAM development environment.

  3. Docker Containers: docker-windows

    – Equivilant to the WSL/WSL2 approach.

    – The entire OpenFOAM installation/workspace is managed as a container.

Pick only one method

WSL/WSL2Native WindowsDocker Containers
  1. Install WSL/WSL2: The WSL information from Windows provides installation anf configuration information for WSL.

  2. Choose and install a Linux Distro: Choose a distro such as Ubuntu or openSUSE that recieves regualar OpenFOAM updates.

    For new users I recommend using Ubuntu here

  3. Install OpenFOAM: Follow the regular installation/update instructions for Ubuntu or openSUSE

OpenFOAM requires a case sensitive file system to build. If you build OpenFOAM from a location outside of the WSL/WSL2 partition (eg. a mounted drive, /mnt/c/Users/some/path) this will cause issues. There are two possible solutions to deal with this.

Build in the partitionCreate a case sensitive folder

– Build OpenFOAM within the WSL/WSL2 partition. This partition is case sensitive.

Create a case sensitive folder within the Windows Partition and build OpenFOAM there. As outlined below:

  1. Create a new folder within Windows (eg, ../Documents/OpenFOAM). Folder must be empty for the nest step.
  2. Enable case sensitivity for this folder using fsutil.exe. This is done by running fsutil.exe file setCaseSensitiveInfo <path/to/folder> enable in an elevated PowerShell session.
  3. From inside the WSL/WSL2 environment/terminal, unpack the OpenFOAM-vXXXX.tgz/ThirdParty-vXXXX.tgz files or clone the Git Repos within this folder.
  4. Build OpenFOAM.

There is no need to use WSL/WSL2 to download Paraview, use the Windows version of ParaView

Tested by [name+git]

  1. Download the package of the latest OpenFOAM MinGW version:

    – This package is an executable

    – Run this to open the installation wizard, and follow the instructions.

  2. If needed, install Microsoft MPI (MS-MPI)

  3. Upon completion, an icon will be created on the Desktop:

    – Click this icon to launch a terminal window.

    – Running this will load the OpenFOAM Environment.

    – Verify the contents of OpenFOAM in a terminal: 

    $ ls -p
OpenFOAM/

$ cd $WM_PROJECT_DIR

$ ls -p
bin/  COPYING  etc/  etc-mingw  META-INFO  platforms/  README.md  ThirdParty/  tutorials/

$ is the command prompt, indicating the terminal is ready to accept a command

  1. Install Docker: Follow the Docker manual
  2. Create the OpenFOAM container: Follow the OpenFOAM + Docker instructions

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: A simplified step-by-step overview to quickly get OpenFOAM up and running.

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
CFD workflows in OpenFOAM, and by extension other CFD softwares, follow the steps below; 

flowchart LR
    A(Problem Setup) --> B(Pre-process) --> C(Process) --> D(Post-process)

docs.title: Problem Setup
docs.text:
In OpenFOAM, simulation settings are modified via text files. Each parameter follows a straightforward key-value pairing format. Each file has its own unique set of mandatory and optional keywords. Location and Content of these files vary depending on the chosen solver application, simulation setup and what aspects you wish to modify.

It is necessary to familiarize yourself with the structure and significance of these keywords in relevant files

You can browse the problem setup:

File ExplorerWindowsLinux

Navigate to where the main file was stored.

$ cd $FOAM_TUTORIALS/incompressible/simpleFoam/pitzDaily/

$ ls -p
0/  constant/  system/

$ ls -p system/
blockMeshDict  controlDict  fvSchemes  fvSolution  streamlines

$ ls -p constant/
transportProperties  turbulenceProperties

$ ls -p 0/
epsilon  k  p  U

TEST ON LINUX THEN ADD
